column2: When Diamond's rhymes grew scarce, he always began dancing the baby. Some people wondered that such a child could rhyme as he did, but his rhymes were not very good, for he was only trying to remember what he had heard the river sing at the back of the north wind.

column2: DIAMOND GOES ON

column2: DIAMOND became a great favourite with all the men about the mews.

column2: Some may think it was not the best place in the world for him to be brought up in; but it must have been, for there he was.

column2: At first, he heard a good many rough and bad words; but he did not like them, and so they did him little harm.

column2: He did not know in the least what they meant, but there was something in the very sound of them, and in the tone of voice in which they were said, which Diamond felt to be ugly.
column3: He did not know in the least what they meant, but there was something in the very sound of them, and in the tone of voice in which they were said, which Diamond felt to be ugly.

column2: So they did not even stick to him, not to say get inside him.
column3: So they did not even stick to him, not to say get inside him.

column2: He never took any notice of them, and his face shone pure and good in the middle of them, like a primrose in a hailstorm.
column3: He never took any notice of them, and his face shone pure and good in the middle of them, like a primrose in a hailstorm.

column2: At first, because his face was so quiet and sweet, with a smile always either awake or asleep in his eyes, and because he never heeded their ugly words and rough jokes, they said he wasn't all there, meaning that he was half an idiot, whereas he was a great deal more there than they had the sense to see.

column2: Give me a leg, said Diamond, and in a moment he was on the old horse's back with the comb and brush.
column3: Give me a leg, said Diamond, and in a moment he was on the old horse's back with the comb and brush.

column2: He sat on his withers, and reaching forward as he ate his hay, he curried and he brushed, first at one side of his neck, and then at the other.
column3: He sat on his withers, and reaching forward as he ate his hay, he curried and he brushed, first at one side of his neck, and then at the other.

column2: When that was done he asked for a dressing-comb, and combed his mane thoroughly.
column3: When that was done he asked for a dressing comb, and combed his mane thoroughly.

column2: Then he pushed himself on to his back, and did his shoulders as far down as he could reach.
column3: Then he pushed himself on to his back, and did his shoulders as far down as he could reach.

column2: Then he sat on his croup, and did his back and sides; then he turned around like a monkey, and attacked his hind-quarters, and combed his tail.
column3: Then he sat on his croup, and did his back and sides; then he turned around like a monkey, and attacked his hind quarters, and combed his tail.

column2: This last was not so easy to manage, for he had to lift it up, and every now and then old Diamond would whisk it out of his hands, and once he sent the comb flying out of the stable door, to the great amusement of the men.
